entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower: Q2 2025 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the first half of 2025, global sustainability governance has entered a new phase of scrutiny and recalibration. The EU Omnibus amendments to the CSRD have postponed timelines and reduced the scope of immediate obligations for thousands of companies, temporarily easing the pressure of compliance. However, this regulatory pause has only sharpened the spotlight on data integrity, preparedness, and strategic ESG integration. 

At the same time, investors, regulators, and civil society are intensifying their expectations. Public disclosures are no longer judged on completeness alone‚Äîthey must be audit-ready, aligned with recognized frameworks like ESRS and EU Taxonomy. Companies are expected to move beyond box-ticking compliance into continuous ESG performance management, proactively steering their sustainability journey. 

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) is designed precisely for this challenge. It enables organizations to: 

  • Record ESG factors with out-of-the-box integration to SAP systems and trusted third-party sources 
  • Analyze performance across financial, operational, and sustainability dimensions to support informed decisions 
  • Accelerate the transition through auditable, framework-aligned reporting‚Äîcovering both regulatory and voluntary disclosures, powered by AI 

Building on our momentum from Q1, this quarter's updates focus on strengthening ESRS-aligned metric coverage, deeper analytical flexibility, improved auditability, and tighter alignment with financial structures. 

 

Expansion of SAP-provided metric coverage   

To support organizations on their ESRS compliance journey, SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) continues to expand its library of SAP-provided metrics aligned with the European Sustainability Reporting Standards. These include both qualitative and quantitative definitions based on EFRAG's implementation guidance. Current metric coverage is available in the SAP Help Portal and detailed in the SAP Community blog, offering transparency and reuse for accelerated implementation.  

 

Looking ahead, we plan to reach approximately 80% coverage of ESRS data points by the end of 2025, including metrics from ESRS 2, S2‚ÄìS4, G1, and additional quantitative metrics from ESRS Topical Standards. This roadmap aims to enable our customers to progressively adopt SCT content for structured, auditable, and regulation-ready ESG disclosures while maintaining flexibility to extend for sector-specific or company-specific needs. 

 

Analyze ESG Data App Enhancements 

The Analyze ESG Data application now offers a significantly improved analytics experience with the introduction of the Analytics tab. Users can explore all standard custom quantitative metrics in greater depth by applying drill-down dimensions, choosing between chart or table formats, and configuring default views tailored to reporting needs. This new flexibility allows up to three charts to be displayed simultaneously, each with independent metric, period, and structure settings. 

In parallel, users can manage and switch between saved configurations of grouped metric tiles (‚ÄúOverviews‚Äù), enabling different perspectives for different stakeholders or strategic priorities. Together, these enhancements empower users to personalize and streamline how ESG data is analyzed, viewed, and shared ‚Äì supporting more informed decision-making and stronger alignment with sustainability goals. Find full details here: Using the Analyze ESG Data Application.

 

Custom Templates for ‚ÄúGenerate ESG Reports with AI‚Äù App 

The Generate ESG Reports with AI app now offers greater flexibility and control through the introduction of custom templates. Users can create or edit templates to tailor the structure and content of ESG reports using available SAP-provided quantitative metrics.  

Within the Templates section, you can now select ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù to build a new template or modify an existing one by adding sections and subsections, defining narrative text, and selecting from a predefined list of charts and tables. For each component, a content preview is available to ensure alignment with the selected reporting period. Once finalized, templates can be saved and reused, enabling consistent and structured ESG reporting across time periods.  

When generating a report, you can preview or download the result as a PDF‚Äîand for added customization, you can edit any section manually. SAP's built-in AI-assistance now supports dynamic revisions: simply select a passage and use the ‚ÄúRevise‚Äù option to receive suggestions to shorten or lengthen the text, helping refine your final ESG narrative with ease and speed. 

 

Fiscal Period Support 

The new Manage Fiscal Year Variants app brings flexible fiscal period support to SAP Sustainability Control Tower, allowing customers to define and activate custom fiscal year variants that align with their internal planning cycles. Whether using standard calendar months or granular date-based periods (like semi-monthly ranges), organizations can now tailor their ESG data analysis and reporting across key apps such as Analyze ESG Data, Manage GHG Data, and View Emission Dashboard. Built-in validation checks help ensure data compatibility, with options to consolidate or reimport data when switching to a new variant. This enables more accurate reporting, tighter alignment with financial periods, and greater control over how sustainability data is structured and interpreted across the organization. 

 

Change log updates 

In Q2, we've significantly improved transparency and traceability across SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT). Users can now track create, update, and delete changes to public overview configurations in the Analyze ESG Data app using the View Change Logs app. This functionality extends further, providing detailed logs for changes in business activity data, clearly showing the number of updated or imported records and distinguishing between actual and target data. 

 

New Languages Supported 

To better serve global enterprises, SAP SCT now supports Turkish and Italian languages. This update enables local teams to work in their native languages and enhances cross-regional collaboration on sustainability data collection and reporting. 

 

H2 2025 Roadmap Updates 

Looking ahead, we‚Äôre focused on simplifying and harmonizing ESG data consumption and reporting. A key milestone will be the delivery of a unified Read API for metric values ‚Äì supporting both quantitative and qualitative data ‚Äì to  make calculated ESG metrics easily accessible to external tools like disclosure management platforms. This API will also expose key metadata (including ESG standard references) and allow for both bulk and individual metric retrieval based on reporting scopes. We‚Äôre also working on improving flexibility in data modeling by enabling custom account groups, account-to-group mappings, and supporting activity data input through multiple channels. Additionally, we‚Äôll continue expanding metric-level analysis, measure drilldowns, and export formats in the Analyze ESG data application. To enhance data quality and reporting alignment, we‚Äôre introducing tools for guiding data requirements based on double materiality, setting up reporting hierarchies and data sources, and improving transparency on data completeness. In parallel, we aim to deliver ESRS-aligned metric definitions that cover up to 70% of EFRAG's guidance, along with clear documentation and community updates to keep you informed as mentioned above. Stay tuned: SCT Roadmap Explorer. 

 

Additional Information 

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Control Tower, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What‚Äôs New section, which is updated with every new software release.

entry.title: SAP Green Token H1-25 Updates & Highlights: Raising the Bar on Sustainability Compliance
entry.content:
As sustainability regulations tighten, and global supply chains grow more complex,  SAP Green Token    continues to deliver pragmatic solutions for chain-of-custody, compliance, and operational clarity. Our H1 2025 release focuses on deepening support for the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR)

 

Making EUDR Work for Complex Supply Chains

SAP Green Token  delivers extended support for Article 9 of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR), covering both operator and trader personas‚Äîfrom inbound geolocation capture to DDS number generation and outbound data transfer

We built these capabilities for enterprise complexity. Whether managing dozens of sites, importing from outside the EU, or reducing supplier risk, Green Token simplifies compliance and provides a future-ready foundation.

‚úÖHighlights from the H1 release:

  • Operator & Trader support: DDS generation, handling EU and non-EU suppliers, TRACES integration
  • Transactional-level reporting: Built on ERP data, avoids duplication, reduces risk
  • Open API integrations: Import GeoJSON and DDS data from portals, GR processes, or external systems

Figure 1: All end-to-end scenarios covered in SAP Green Token in H1

üîÑSupporting Article 9 Workflows for the EU and Beyond

Global supply chains rarely follow a single linear flow. Most large enterprises manage multiple flows in parallel‚Äîacross sites, regions, and regulatory jurisdictions. SAP Green Token is designed to handle exactly that.

We support inbound and outbound flow combinations under the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) including movements between EU and non-EU regions and across internal company sites. This enables companies to track, validate, and document material origin and DDS data across their full supply network‚Äîregardless of geography or supply chain complexity.

üì•Built-In TRACES Integration
Green Token is directly connected to the EU TRACES system, enabling automated submission and tracking of DDS for both inbound and outbound shipments.

Based on your role (operator or trader), and the material flow direction, Green Token intelligently determines when to trigger TRACES submissions‚Äîminimizing errors, delays, and manual work. Simulation mode is also available for safe testing before go-live.

Why Transactional Reporting Matters

Most companies rely on annual reporting to track sustainability data‚Äîan approach still allowed under the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR). However, annual summaries can introduce risks, including outdated data, limited traceability, and delayed issue detection.

SAP Green Token offers an alternative: transactional-level reporting, seamlessly integrated with your ERP. This approach captures data per shipment, enabling real-time traceability, smarter DDS volume management, and proactive compliance.

‚úÖBenefits:

  • More control: Filter by supplier, origin, or shipment quality
  • Risk isolation: One bad shipment won‚Äôt impact the entire batch
  • Smarter volume use: Avoid early DDS exhaustion
  • Lower long-term cost: Minimize corrections, fines, and rework

 

üéØOur Focus: Article 9, Done Exceptionally Well

SAP Green Token is purpose-built to support Article 9 of the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR)‚Äîthe most operationally complex and compliance-critical part of the regulation. Our solution is designed to handle the transactional- and geolocation-level data management, organization, and submission required of operators and traders at scale.

Green Token provides deep SAP integration, automated DDS management, TRACES submission, and audit-ready traceability, all optimized for ERP-driven supply chains.

üß© We also leave white space for partners to extend the platform. For example, NTT Data independently built a supplier data management extension on top of Green Token for a customer‚Äîand we‚Äôre now exploring how to scale that model across the ecosystem.

This modular and integration-friendly approach enables customers and partners to build what's right for their workflows‚Äîwithout adding cost or complexity where it's not needed.

 

Enablement & Go-To-Market Assets: Everything You Need to Succeed

We released a full library of go-to-market and training assets to help teams implement Green Token.

Highlights include:

  • ISCC and EUDR demo systems
  • FAQs, L2 decks, pricing guides, onboarding content
  • Bi-monthly training sessions via Partner Portal
  • Integration & API guides

 

What‚Äôs Coming Next?

In H2 2025, we‚Äôre expanding into a completely new use case with support for the EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), marking Green Token‚Äôs first step into carbon-related compliance. We‚Äôll also continue to strengthen our EUDR offering to support evolving regulatory and customer needs.

Curious how we‚Äôre tackling CBAM? Explore our first wave of materials here:

  • üìÑThe 6 things every CFO should do to prepare for CBAM ‚Äî Thought leadership article by Gunther Rothermel on CFO.com
  • üåêWhat is EU CBAM? ‚Äî A quick-read content hub that answers key questions and explains SAP‚Äôs role
  • üé•Watch now: CBAM Declarant Reporting with SAP Green Token ‚Äì our new video walkthrough of how the solution supports CBAM compliance 

 

Stay in Touch

We‚Äôre committed to delivering solutions that solve real problems‚Äîand we want to hear from you.

  • Submit feedback via the SAP Influence Portal
  • Request a demo via your SAP representative
  • Follow me on SAP Community

entry.title: A Step-by-Step Guide to Implementing an Excel Upload Button in a Fiori App using RAP
entry.content:
Live Demo

Here is a short video demonstrating the final Excel upload functionality in action.

 

For this demonstration, I've built a simple RAP application with a V4 UI. The application features an "Employee" table with three fields. The base of the application was created using the RAP generator, and I've also included early numbering logic for the Employee ID.

Step 1: Create a Fiori Project

To begin, create a new SAP Fiori project using the List Report template. This will serve as the foundation for our application.

Step 2: Add a Custom Button

With the project set up, the next step is to add a custom button. You can do this by using the open guided development feature. From there, choose the option to Add a Custom Action to a Page Using Extensions. Follow the prompts in the guide to insert the necessary code snippets for the "Excel Upload" button.

 

 

or 

Step 2: Configure the manifest.json File

The manifest.json file is the application descriptor, defining its structure, data sources, and routing. To add the "Excel Upload" button, you need to modify this file to define a custom action and extend the standard List Report controller with our custom logic.

You can either use the "Add a Custom Action to a Page Using Extensions" option in the guided development tool or update the manifest.json file directly with the following configuration. Pay close attention to the controlConfiguration and extends sections, which are key to enabling this functionality.

{
  "_version": "1.53.0",
  "sap.app": {
    "id": "uploadempexcel",
    "type": "application",
    "i18n": "i18n/i18n.properties",
    "applicationVersion": {
      "version": "0.0.1"
    },
    "title": "{{appTitle}}",
    "description": "{{appDescription}}",
    "resources": "resources.json",
    "sourceTemplate": {
      "id": "@sap/generator-fiori:lrop",
      "version": "1.18.2",
      "toolsId": "f8a70d19-c3d7-40bf-9b4b-03ba34f86143"
    },
    "dataSources": {
      "mainService": {
        "uri": "/sap/opu/odata4/sap/zui_upload_emp_o4/srvd/sap/zui_upload_emp_o4/0001/",
        "type": "OData",
        "settings": {
          "annotations": ["annotation"],
          "localUri": "localService/mainService/metadata.xml",
          "odataVersion": "4.0"
        }
      }
    }
  },
  "sap.ui5": {
    "flexEnabled": true,
    "dependencies": {
      "minUI5Version": "1.114.9",
      "libs": {
        "sap.m": {},
        "sap.ui.core": {},
        "sap.fe.templates": {}
      }
    },
    "routing": {
      "routes": [
        {
          "pattern": ":?query:",
          "name": "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList",
          "target": "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList"
        }
      ],
      "targets": {
        "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList": {
          "type": "Component",
          "id": "ZC_UPLOAD_EMPList",
          "name": "sap.fe.templates.ListReport",
          "options": {
            "settings": {
              "contextPath": "/ZC_UPLOAD_EMP",
              "controlConfiguration": {
                "@com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1.LineItem": {
                  "actions": {
                    "uploadExcelController.controller": {
                      "press": ".extension.uploadempexcel.ext.controller.uploadExcelController.uploadExcel",
                      "visible": true,
                      "enabled": true,
                      "requiresSelection": false,
                      "text": "Upload Excel"
                    }
                  }
                }
              }
            }
          }
        }
      }
    },
    "extends": {
      "extensions": {
        "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
          "sap.fe.templates.ListReport.ListReportController": {
            "controllerName": "uploadempexcel.ext.controller.uploadExcelController"
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Step 3: Create a Fragment for the Pop-up Screen

You'll need to create a fragment in the ext folder. This fragment will define the pop-up screen that appears when a user clicks the "Excel Upload" button.

 

<core:FragmentDefinition xmlns="sap.m" xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" xmlns:upload="sap.m.upload">
    <Dialog id="uploadDialogSet" title="Excel Upload">
        <content>
            <upload:UploadSet
                id="uploadSet"
                maxFileNameLength="200"
                fileTypes="xlsx, xls"
                afterItemAdded=".onAfterItemAdded"
                afterItemRemoved=".onAfterItemRemoved"
                uploadEnabled="true"
                />
        </content>
        <!-- CORRECTED: Changed from <buttons> to <beginButton> and <endButton> -->
        <beginButton>
            <Button id="idUploadB" text="Upload" press=".onUploadPress" type="Emphasized" enabled="false"/>
        </beginButton>
        <endButton>
            <Button id="idCancelB" text="Cancel" press=".onCloseDialog" />
        </endButton>
    </Dialog>
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Step 4: Implement the Controller Logic

The main logic for handling the file upload is contained within the uploadExcelController.controller.js file. You can adapt the code below for your own application. Make sure to adjust the file name and payload column names to fit your specific needs.

sap.ui.define(
  [
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension",
    "sap/m/MessageToast",
    "sap/ui/core/Fragment",
    "xlsx",
  ],
  function (ControllerExtension, MessageToast, Fragment, XLSX) {
    "use-strict";

    return ControllerExtension.extend(
      "uploadempexcel.ext.controller.uploadExcelController",
      {
        _pDialog: null,
        _file: null,

        uploadExcel: function () {
          if (!this._pDialog) {
            this._pDialog = Fragment.load({
              id: this.base.getView().getId(),
              name: "uploadempexcel.ext.fragment.uploadExcelFragment",
              controller: this,
            }).then(
              function (oDialog) {
                this.base.getView().addDependent(oDialog);
                return oDialog;
              }.bind(this)
            );
          }

          this._pDialog.then(
            function (oDialog) {
              oDialog.open();
              oDialog.getContent()[0].removeAllItems();
              this._file = null;
              var oUploadButton = oDialog.getBeginButton();
              if (oUploadButton) {
                oUploadButton.setEnabled(false);
              }
            }.bind(this)
          );
        },

        onCloseDialog: function () {
          this._pDialog.then(function (oDialog) {
            oDialog.close();
          });
        },

        onAfterItemAdded: function (oEvent) {
          this._file = oEvent.getParameter("item").getFileObject();
          if (this._file) {
            MessageToast.show(
              "File '" + this._file.name + "' is ready for upload."
            );
          }
          this._pDialog.then(
            function (oDialog) {
              var oUploadButton = oDialog.getBeginButton();
              if (oUploadButton) {
                oUploadButton.setEnabled(!!this._file);
              }
            }.bind(this)
          );
        },

        onAfterItemRemoved: function (oEvent) {
          this._file = null;
          this._pDialog.then(function (oDialog) {
            var oUploadButton = oDialog.getBeginButton();
            if (oUploadButton) {
              oUploadButton.setEnabled(false);
            }
          });
          MessageToast.show("File removed.");
        },

        onUploadPress: function () {
          if (!this._file) {
            MessageToast.show("Please select a file first.");
            return;
          }

          var oReader = new FileReader();
          oReader.onload = function (e) {
            try {
              var data = e.target.result;
              var workbook = XLSX.read(data, { type: "buffer" });
              var sheetName = workbook.SheetNames[0];
              var excelData = XLSX.utils.sheet_to_row_object_array(
                workbook.Sheets[sheetName]
              );

              if (excelData.length > 0) {
                this._callOdataService(excelData);
              } else {
                MessageToast.show("No data found in the Excel file.");
              }
            } catch (error) {
              MessageToast.show("Error reading Excel file: " + error.message);
            }
          }.bind(this);

          oReader.readAsArrayBuffer(this._file);
        },

        _callOdataService: function (excelData) {
          try {
            // --- START: FINAL CORRECTED CODE ---
            // Get the main OData V4 model from the view.
            var oModel = this.base.getView().getModel();

            // Create a ListBinding directly for the entity set of the List Report.
            // The path MUST match the 'contextPath' in your manifest.json for the List Report target.
            var oListBinding = oModel.bindList("/ZC_UPLOAD_EMP");
            // --- END: FINAL CORRECTED CODE ---

            if (!oListBinding) {
              // This error is now highly unlikely to occur.
              throw new Error(
                "Could not create a ListBinding for the path /ZC_UPLOAD_EMP."
              );
            }

            excelData.forEach(function (rowData) {
              // IMPORTANT: Make sure your Excel column headers match exactly
              var oPayload = {
                //EmpID: rowData.EmployeeID.toString(), auto generated by Early Numbering in RAP Application
                Empname: rowData.EmployeeName.toString(),
                Contact: rowData.Contact.toString(),
              };
              // The create operation is performed on the ListBinding instance.
              oListBinding.create(oPayload);
            });

            MessageToast.show("Uploading " + excelData.length + " records...");

            // The model holds the batch queue, so we submit the changes on the model.
            oModel
              .submitBatch("$auto")
              .then(
                function () {
                  MessageToast.show("Data uploaded successfully.");
                  this.base.getExtensionAPI().refresh(); // Refresh the table to show new data
                  this.onCloseDialog();
                }.bind(this)
              )
              .catch(function (oError) {
                MessageToast.show("Error during upload: " + oError.message);
              });
          } catch (error) {
            MessageToast.show("Error processing data: " + error.message);
          }
        },
      }
    );
  }
);

Dependencies

Before you can run the application, you'll need to install the necessary dependencies. You can do this by running the following commands in your terminal.

npm i ui5-tooling-modules
npm i xlsx

We also need to update your ui5.yaml file by adding the following custom tasks.

builder:
customTasks:
- name: ui5-tooling-modules-task
afterTask: replaceVersion
- name: ui5-tooling-modules-middleware
afterMiddleware: compression

Conclusion

By following these steps, you can add a fully functional Excel upload feature to your SAP Fiori application. This enhancement provides a more convenient way for users to handle bulk data uploads, ultimately improving the user experience. I have also prepared a demo Excel file with sample data that you can use for testing purposes.

entry.title: Bridging the gap with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper
entry.content:
With the extended maintenance end date rapidly approaching for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition releases 1503, 1603, 1709 - 1909, it is time for impacted customers to start planning their next steps before entering customer-specific maintenance on January 1, 2026. ‚ÄØ

Mainstream maintenance, extended maintenance, and customer-specific maintenance are the three distinct maintenance phases applicable to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition under the SAP Maintenance Strategy.‚ÄØ 

During mainstream maintenance, full support (SAP Notes, Support packages, Support package stacks, Feature package stacks, etc) is offered for a SAP product until a successor product is available. Extended maintenance offers similar support but requires a specific maintenance contract. For RISE customers, extended maintenance for S/4HANA Cloud private edition is covered by the regular annual subscription fee and does not require a specific maintenance addendum. Once extended maintenance ends, systems enter customer-specific maintenance (CSM), a phase with limited and restricted support services. Entering CSM as a RISE customer means the support and Service Level Agreement currently provided by SAP Enterprise Cloud Services will no longer be available.

‚ÄØS/4HANA Maintenance Timelines ‚ÄØ 

‚ÄØ 

To fully leverage the value of SAP, it's essential for customers to keep their S/4HANA release up to date - ensuring robust security, continuous innovation and optimal system performance. For this reason, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service has been released to support RISE with SAP customers who have not yet upgraded to the latest S/4HANA Cloud, private edition version and are at risk of falling into customer-specific maintenance.‚ÄØ‚ÄØNew customers who have not yet upgraded must upgrade before moving to RISE. Alternatively, they can move to RISE on their current S/4HANA release before entering customer-specific maintenance, as long as they also purchase the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service. Customer-specific maintenance is not supported for new RISE customers. Safekeeper services are only applicable to S/4HANA Cloud releases, not SAP ERP.  

 

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper service is purchased as a single sales SKU and includes:‚ÄØ 

1) Upgrade Services‚ÄØ 

A) SAP Cloud Application Services (CAS) for Release Version Upgrade‚ÄØ 

OR‚ÄØ 

B) SAP Cloud Application Services (CAS) for Regression Testing‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

‚ÄØ 

2) Infrastructure‚ÄØ 

An additional non-productive sandbox tier is provided by SAP to match the size of the existing production system up to 6TiB. ‚ÄØ 

 

3) Maintenance-related services‚ÄØ 

Your existing S/4HANA landscape entering customer-specific maintenance will continue to receive SAP Notes and corrections generally aligning with the scope of Extended Maintenance. It will mitigate the limitations of the customer-specific maintenance for the contracted period.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

 

Let‚Äôs look at two real-world scenarios.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

Example #1 In-Place Upgrade from S/4HANA 1809 to S/4HANA 2023

I'm a RISE with SAP customer running SAP S/4HANA release 1809 which will enter customer-specific maintenance on January 1st, 2026.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ I want to upgrade my existing systems to SAP S/4HANA 2023.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

In this scenario, the customer purchases SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper at least 90 days prior to the safekeeper contract start date (Sept-30-2025) and opts for the upgrade service a) CAS for Release Version Upgrade. Customer has a production system RAM of 1TB.

As of January 1, 2026, the safekeeper service will be initiated. This includes:‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

  • ‚ÄØ Deployment of the sandbox infrastructure (copy of existing production system running S/4HANA 1809)‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
  • Commencement of the CAS services‚ÄØ 
  • SAP Notes and corrections on the existing S/4HANA 1809 landscape  

Following the infrastructure deployment, an upgrade planning workshop is scheduled with CAS delivery team to provide a detailed project plan. Any additional infrastructure for a parallel landscape (e.g. development/ testing) will need to be procured separately. SAP specialists guide, navigate, and support the upgrade/update process as a whole. On-going support is offered until the production go-live.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

Example Brownfield Scenario‚ÄØ 

‚ÄØ 

Further reading‚ÄØ 
CAS for Release Version Upgrade Scope Document: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements/services/scope-documents.html?sort=latest_desc&search=release%20version%20upgrade‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

How to upgrade blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/upgrade-your-sap-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-following-sap-activate/ba-p/13956251‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

 

#2 Greenfield/ Selective Data Transition‚ÄØ 

I'm a RISE with SAP customer running SAP S/4HANA release 1909 entering customer-specific maintenance on January 1, 2026.‚ÄØ I do not want to upgrade my existing systems, but instead, implement a new installation of systems on a more current release.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

In this scenario, the suitable upgrade service is b) CAS for Regression Testing.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

As of January 1, 2026, the safekeeper service will be initiated. This includes:‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

  • ‚ÄØ Deployment of the sandbox infrastructure (empty greenfield system with the desired target release e.g. 2023)‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 
  • Commencement of the CAS package for Regression Testing‚ÄØ 
  • SAP Notes and corrections on the existing S/4HANA 1909 landscape  

Implementing a greenfield S/4HANA deployment typically involves replicating or redesigning previous business processes or adopting SAP best practices. These processes can be tested and validated in the new sandbox environment before implementing in other tiers. Customer will need to procure additional systems (DEV, QAS and PRD) based on the project plan.

Example Greenfield Scenario‚ÄØ 

‚ÄØ 

Further reading‚ÄØ

entry.title: Developing a Customized AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction:

Hello everyone, Myself Sriram Balaji, I am currently working as an SAP FICO Consultant. Last year, I got an opportunity to work in SAP Public Cloud Greenfield Implementation Project. During the ‚ÄúFIT to Standard‚Äù and ‚ÄúUAT‚Äù sessions, we have demonstrated the SAP standard Customer / Supplier Aging Analysis Report to the client but they are not satisfied with the standard aging report. They required a tailored Aging Analysis Report for Customer and Supplier, one that aligned perfectly with their unique operational requirements. This experience highlighted the importance of understanding client expectations beyond standard functionalities and fueled my journey into customizing SAP solutions in the Public Cloud.

In this blog, we are going to explore how we can develop Customized Customer (AR) Aging Analysis Report using the ‚ÄúKey User Extensibility‚Äù in the SAP Public Cloud.

 

Purpose of Preparing Customer Aging Analysis Report:

Customer Aging Analysis Report, is a basic financial report which provides the information of outstanding payment from the customer‚Äôs and how long they are due for the payment by categorizing into the Aging Buckets (0 ‚Äì 30 Days, 31 ‚Äì 60 Days, ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. Above 365 Days).

The aging report provides vital information to management to evaluate how effective the business is at converting sales to cash. The aging report is also used as a tool for estimating potential bad debts, which are then used to revise what is known as the allowance for doubtful accounts.

 

Key-User Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud:

Extensibility covers a broad spectrum of topics that enable customers and partners to adapt standard business software to their business needs.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud key user extensibility allows adapting standard functionalities to user requirements without the need for any external tools. Key User Extensibility is done in the customizing tenant of the development system through SAP Fiori apps designed to facilitate someone making small changes to apps, reports, and email and form templates without any coding experience.

Here's an overview of the things you can do using key user extensibility tools:

  • Change and adapt the UIs for SAP Fiori Apps
  • Create Custom Fields
  • Create your own custom templates or extend the standard forms and email templates
  • Create customer-specific CDS Views
  • Enhance the current business process by creating custom business logic
  • Create a new custom user interface
  • Create custom business objects

SAP S/4HANA embodies key user extensibility tools, which are completely web-based. They are targeted at key users who have a deep knowledge of the product itself, but not necessarily a very deep technical knowledge.

For more details about Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud, please refer the link https://extensibilityexplorer.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/ExtensibilityExplorer/#/ReadMore

To develop the Customized Customer Aging Analysis Report, we are going to use the below Key-User Extensibility Apps and other provided Apps by SAP in the Public Cloud:

  • Custom CDS View APP
  • Custom Analytical Queries APP
  • View Browser APP
  • Custom Catalog Extensions APP

My prior experience in developing Aging Analysis Reports in SAP ECC and S/4HANA GUI with my technical team allowed me to apply the same logic to Custom CDS Views and Custom Analytical Queries, even without knowing any deep technical knowledge.

Let me summarize the business requirement for Customer Aging Analysis before jumping into the technical steps involved for the development:

  • The report should display: Customer Account, Customer Name, Document Number, Line Item, Document Type, GL Account, Payment Terms (with descriptions), and other required fields.
  • The report should calculate and present: Overdue Days, Not Yet Due, Aging Buckets (0-30 days, 31-60 days, ‚Ä¶... and Above 365 days), and Total Overdue Amount.
  • The report balances must be matched with the 'Manage Customer Line Items' App (Accounts Receivable Ledger).

 

In this Part - 1, We will explore how we can utilize the Custom CDS View APP for the AR Aging Analysis Report development.

 

Custom CDS View:

Custom CDS views can serve different purposes: They can be consumed in analytics or serve as external APIs to be consumed in external systems, for instance the SAP BTP. Especially Cube or Dimension views can be used in analytical scenarios and also you can create or modify a custom CDS view by,

  • Adding fields from multiple data sources.
  • Creating your own calculated fields.
  • Refining the properties of the selected fields.
  • Creating and maintaining parameters for the usage within your view.

We have combined the multiple data sources such as I_JournalEntryOperationalView, _I_GLAccountText, and _I_PaymentTermsText to create a Custom CDS View by using the Join Condition.

 

Step ‚Äì 1: Open the APP ‚Äì Custom CDS View

Click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

 

Enter the ‚ÄúLabel‚Äù, Choose the ‚ÄúScenario‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúAnalytical Cube‚Äù and Click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù Button.

Note: By choosing the Scenario as ‚ÄúAnalytical Cube‚Äù, We can use this CDS View to create an Analytical Queries for the Customer Aging Analysis report.

 

Step ‚Äì 2: Choose the Primary Data Source 

Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù Button

Choose the ‚ÄúPrimary Data Source‚Äù

Note: Data Source is an object containing the key figures and characteristics from the database and it provides a multidimensional analytical view of business data.

 

Select the respective ‚ÄúI_JournalEntryOperationalView‚Äù Data Source from the list.

 

This I_JournalEntryOperationalView CDS view provides access to all details of a journal entry item (database table ACDOCA) joined to the details of the corresponding operational accounting document item (database table BSEG) and to the details of the corresponding journal entry header (database table BKPF) including the most important business entity, such as G/L account, Cost Center or Profit Center.

So, this I_JournalEntryOperationalView is similar to the ACDOCA Table which contains the values of all the relevant fields related to the Accounting Document.

 

Step ‚Äì 3: Choose the Associated Data Sources

Click on ‚ÄúAssociated Data Sources‚Äù

Note: Associated Data Sources will help us to combine the two different data sources into one CDS View by using a join condition set between two or more equal characteristics present in the Primary Data Source ‚Äì A and Associated Date Sources ‚Äì B that contains the same data type.

For Example:

The primary data source "I_JournalEntryOperationalView" does not include the "Payment Terms Description" field. Therefore, we must join it with the associated data source "I_PaymentTermsText" using a join condition to retrieve this field.

Select the ‚ÄúJoin Condition‚Äù Icon.

 

Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù

 

Choose the common field that available in the both Primary & Associated Data Source to join.

 

Select the Value Type as ‚ÄúField‚Äù

Click on F4 in the Value Field.

 

Find the corresponding "Payment Terms" mapping field in the Primary Data Source to link it with the field in the Associated Data Source.

 

Select the Value Type as ‚ÄúSession Variable‚Äù

Choose the Value as ‚ÄúSystem Language‚Äù and Click on ‚ÄúClose‚Äù button.

 

Step ‚Äì 4: Choose the Elements (Fields) to be added in the CDS View

In the Elements Section, Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button and Choose ‚ÄúElements‚Äù.

In the Elements selection pop up screen,

Choose the ‚ÄúElements (Fields)‚Äù from ‚ÄúI_JournalEntryOperationalView‚Äù you want to display in the CDS view and then Click on ‚ÄúOK‚Äù.

Total 142 Elements (Fields) have been selected for the CDS view.

 

Step ‚Äì 5: Create User Defined Parameters

User-Defined Parameters:

Parameters usually require data input when your custom CDS view is executed. This data can then be used like a variable e.g. in filters, calculated fields or even in a join condition to another view. You can then refine them or just create your own parameters if you need them.

The Customer Aging Analysis Report will operate based on "Open Items at Key Date," mirroring the functionality found in reports like "Manage Customer Line Item" or "FBL5N."

The "Open Items at Key Date" logic ensures that when the report is run for a specific date (which can be in the past, present, or future), it will only display items that meet following criteria mentioned below:

  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were not yet cleared as of the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared after the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared before the specified key date will be excluded from the report.

This "Key Date" will serve as a crucial input on the report's selection screen, driving the logic for determining which open items are included in the Customer Aging Report.

In the Parameters Section, Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button,

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Data Type: ‚ÄúDATS‚Äù ‚Äì Date (YYYYMMDD Format) Data type of the parameter.
  • Default Type and Value: ‚ÄúManual‚Äù - Enter a manual parameter value in accordance with the data type syntax, e.g. for the data type DATS enter a manual value in the format YYYYMMDD.

Now the ‚ÄúOpen Items at Key Date‚Äù Parameter is created. 

 

Step ‚Äì 6: Add User Defined Parameters in the Elements (Fields)

In the Elements Section, Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù Button and Choose the ‚ÄúParameters‚Äù.

Select the created ‚ÄúOpen Items at Key Date‚Äù Parameter and Click on ‚ÄúOK‚Äù button.

Now the ‚ÄúOpen Items at Key Date‚Äù Parameter has been added in the Elements.

 

Step ‚Äì 7: Using ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù Applying the Logic for the Customer Aging Analysis Report

You can filter the information shown in your custom CDS view by setting up a condition, just like using the WHERE clause in SQL. This condition provides the view exactly what data to show.

Think of it like this:

The CDS view (I_JournalEntryOperationalView) which we are using that shows all the Accounting Document transactions in line item wise.

  • If you want to display only Customer related Accounting Transactions, you'd set a condition like "Account Type is equal to ‚ÄúD".
  • Or, if you only want to see Normal Transactions (Invoices, Payments) & Special GL Transactions (Advances), your condition would be "Special GL Code equal to ‚ÄúBLANK‚Äù, & ‚ÄúA‚Äù.

Once you set this condition (using either a simple editor or a form-based one), your CDS view will automatically filter its results, showing only the open items that match what you asked for. It's a way to fine-tune the data you see without having to look through everything.

We can use the form-based version to define simple filter conditions. In case you want to define more complex conditions, we can use expression-based version. Here, we have used expression-based version.

As per business requirement, to ensure the Customer Aging Analysis Report balances match with the "Manage Customer Line Items" balances, we've set up specific conditions for these fields: Account Type, Special GL Code, Posting Date, and Clearing Date in the Filter section using expression-based version.

 

Step ‚Äì 8: Create Calculation Elements (Fields) ‚Äì Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days

In the Elements section, click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button and Choose ‚ÄúCalculation‚Äù to create Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days fields for the report.

  1. Overdue Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as ‚ÄúFunction‚Äù and Choose ‚ÄúFunction Type ‚Äì Date and Time‚Äù
  • Choose the respective ‚ÄúFunction - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN‚Äù and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

Note: The function DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN calculates the difference between two specified dates, date1 and date2, in days. The actual parameters must have the predefined data type DATS and should contain a valid date in the format YYYYMMDD.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Overdue Days is Open Items Key Date (which was created as parameter for report execution) MINUS Net Due Date. 

 

  1. Payment Terms Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as ‚ÄúFunction‚Äù and Choose ‚ÄúFunction Type ‚Äì Date and Time‚Äù
  • Choose the respective ‚ÄúFunction - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN‚Äù and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Payment Terms Days is Net Due Date MINUS Baseline Date.

Created Calculation Elements (Fields) for the report.

In the Element Properties Section, Maintain the Aggregation method as ‚ÄúNo Operation‚Äù for the created Payment Term Days & Overdue Days Fields to convert the field into calculated measure for creating the Aging Buckets in the Custom Analytical Query APP.

 

Step ‚Äì 9: Preview and Publish the created CDS view

In the Log section, check any error need to rectified before preview the CDS view.

Click on ‚ÄúPreview Data‚Äù button to display the values are coming as per the logic or not.

 

Created CDS View no of line items are matching with the Manage Customer Line Items.

Calculated Fields (Overdue Days, Payment Terms Days) are displaying with values in the CDS View according formula we have applied in the calculation function.

Once Check is successful, Go to ‚ÄúNext Steps‚Äù section.

Click on ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù button to publish the Created CDS View for Creating Analytical Queries.

In Part - 2, we'll dive into using the Custom Analytical Queries APP with our newly created Custom CDS View to build an AR Aging Analysis Report.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA configuration for SAC pull of plan data
entry.content:
This post deals with the SAP S/4HANA app ‚ÄúManage Financial Plan Data Jobs - for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration‚Äù (in the following referred to as ‚Äúmanage‚Äù app) where mandatory configuration settings for pulling plan data from SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) into SAP S/4HANA tables like ACDOCP or FINSSKF are defined. These configuration settings are prerequisite for the app ‚ÄúSchedule Financial Plan Data Jobs for SAP Analytics Cloud Integration‚Äú to execute a financial plan data job (for data replication). The integration using these two apps is available in SAP S/4HANA Public and Private Cloud Edition.

The goal is to provide guidance on the necessary configuration settings in this manage app and show example configurations based on SAC content for different use cases.

It is recommended to bookmark this post, as we plan to enhance it with further recommendations and configuration settings.

Before creating a configuration, first in the manage app a tenant ID (with communication details) of a SAP Analytics Cloud tenant must be defined which is explained in the following online help:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/1cbcff7ccd35405ab445b223c1ab1588/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US
  • SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/48f4b4785b8e45938ac44a67be8032d9/1d0a86ae5db84da89a56481e9e73b5cf.html?locale=en-US

This post is based on the following SAC content for Integrated Financial Planning with possible plan data replications into S/4HANA tables but apply to other (customer specific) SAC models writing into these S/4HANA tables as well.

To simplify, we assume that depreciations are copied from the SAC model CAPEX to model OPEX and asset values ‚Äã‚Äãfrom the SAC model CAPEX to model Financial Statement Planning. So we only deal with configuration entries for plan data related to OPEX, Sales and Profitability Planning and Financial Statement. CO2 values ‚Äã‚Äãare also ignored (might be addressed in a later version of this post).

We start with functional and technical basics, continue with general recommendations and finally show some example configurations.

Functional Basics

For replication of plan data related to the three IFP models OPEX, Profitability and Financial Statement into SAP S/4HANA, the following SAC modeling details must be considered:

  • In contrast to Profitability and Financial Statement, only OPEX has a dimension for the debit/credit indicator to represent cost charges and discharges. However, for profitability and financial statement data, the debit/credit indicator ‚ÄòD‚Äô is added by default when writing into table ACDOCP. The debit/credit indicator becomes part of the plan data scope explained below.
  • When transferring sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability, the same account used to post into Profitability is used to credit records in OPEX. However, in contrast to OPEX, product and plant information is added to these costs in Profitability.
  • The starting point for financial statement planning is a copy of actual data from the previous year‚Äôs financial statement. Then plan data from OPEX and Profitability are copied into Financial Statement, i.e. these copy processes do NOT result in corresponding credit records on the sender side.
  • The IFP content in SAC offers two possible sources for bringing a profit and loss statement into table ACDOCP:
    • Option 1: The model Financial Statement serves as the source to ensure a complete P&L statement. Since the copy of actual data is used as a starting point, the data can contain recurring extraordinary revenues and costs like the dissolution of accruals etc. 
    • Option 2: The two models OPEX and Profitability serve as the source. Here special attention is required for the account(s) used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Profitability (more on this later). In contrast to Option 1, this option has only operating costs and revenues.

Technical Basics

It is important to understand that contrary to table ACDOCA, table ACDOCP represents a multidimensional view. Therefore, the key fields of table ACDOCP consist of purely technical fields. This makes it necessary to specify a so-called aggregation level and plan data scope when writing data into table ACDOCP. These are explained below (among other technical terms for the Manage app).

  1. Aggregation level
    The aggregation level determines the fields of the records for which plan data is transferred into SAP S/4HANA. In the following mapping view of the configuration for the SAC plan data pull, the listed SAP S/4HANA fields are automatically translated into this aggregation level:
    As you can see in the last four columns of the screenshot above, it does not matter for the derivation of the aggregation level whether the field is mapped 1:1 from SAC, derived from an attribute (of an SAC dimension), or defined as a fixed value.
  2. Plan Data Scope
    The plan data scope influences which existing data records in table ACDOCP are replaced by the new plan data. Therefore, based on the fields marked ‚ÄúIn Scope‚Äù (i.e. plan data scope) and their corresponding values from the plan data (to be written into ACDOCP), a data set is identified in the (multidimensional) table ACDOCP.
    It is important to understand that for the derivation of this ‚Äúdata set‚Äù not only the existing value combinations from the fields marked as ‚ÄúIn Scope‚Äù are used, but also cross-combinations of these field values (see example 3 below).
    The following three scenarios show how new plan data with the respective plan data scope setting overwrites existing data in table ACDOCP.

    The more fields are added to the plan data scope, the fewer existing records can be overwritten with the new data, and thus the impacted data section is smaller (see example 2). This is also the reason why some fields such as the planning category or time-related fields like LedgerFiscalYear or FiscalYearPeriod are mandatory in the plan data scope, so that more data than desired is not accidentally overwritten when writing plan data into ACDOCP.
    In the configuration of the manage application, the plan data scope is defined in following highlighted column of the mapping view.
  3. Interaction between update mode and plan data scope
    Because the update mode for reading the relevant plan data records in SAC is a full update, SAC data is always written as a ‚Äúwhole‚Äù into table ACDOCP. Therefore, for cost-center-related costs, for example, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope (to replace the existing cost-center-related accounts and periods with the new plan data). Another example are project-related costs, where the WBSElement, FiscalYearPeriod and GLAccount should not be added to the plan data scope. This ensures that the new plan data from SAC replaces the existing data in ACDOCP correctly.
  4. Account selection
    In the Filter Settings section of a configuration ID in the Manage app, meaningful data selections via G/L accounts are limited, as hierarchy nodes are not supported for the account field. For example, selecting primary accounts, cost accounts or balance sheet accounts using hierarchy nodes is not supported. Unfortunately, this type of selection is only possible via flat account selection, where the relevant accounts are then listed.
  5. Lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP
    Given that the lock concept for writing into table ACDOCP is based on the SAP S/4HANA fields PlanningCategory, ControllingArea, CompanyCode and LedgerFiscalYear, simultaneously running pull jobs into the same planning category can lock each other (for overlapping controlling areas, company code and fiscal year). However, in SAP S/4HANA no locks can occur if simultaneous pull jobs are writing into different planning categories. Therefore this should be considered when using multiple configuration IDs.

General configuration-specific recommendations

After clarifying some functional and technical basics, let‚Äôs look at the following recommendations for the configuration:

  • In general, overlapping plan data across different configurations which are written into the same planning category inevitably leads to inconsistent data when running the financial plan data jobs for the respective configuration IDs (due to the conflict with the plan data scope and subsequent mutual overwriting). An example of this is the configuration for (total) expenses and another configuration specifically for project-related expenses (subset of total expenses). Therefore, it is important to avoid such cases by defining different plan categories in the mapping section for the SAP S/4HANA field PlanningCategory.
  • Plan data from the IFP model Financial Statement must always kept in a separate planning category (in contrast to plan data from the IFP models OPEX and Sales & Profitability) to avoid inconsistencies due to duplicate figures. The reason is that OPEX und Sales & Profitability data is copied into the SAC model Financial Statement without crediting on the sender side.
  • In the case of writing OPEX and Profitability data into one planning category (for an alternative P&L report in SAP S/4HANA), having the field GLAccount as an additional ‚ÄúIn Scope‚Äù field helps differentiate the two data sets (to avoid mutual overwrite), if OPEX and Sales & Profitability use different GL accounts. However, if, for example, a single GL account is used to transfer sales and administration costs from OPEX to Sales and Profitability, this approach no longer ensures disjoint data, and the plan data scope must be expanded. If, as shown in the following example, OPEX consists only of cost center data (and is marked as ‚ÄúIn Scope‚Äù), and all Sales & Profitability data has a Plant, Sold Material and Customer allocation (and is marked as ‚ÄúIn Scope‚Äù), disjoint data is ensured as well (without mutual overwrite):
  • A mapping of profit center and functional area values for a given configuration ID in the view ‚ÄùMapping of Financial Plan Data‚Äù ‚Äã‚Äã(to transfer both fields from SAC) is optional for OPEX and Profitability, since both would be automatically derived in the ACDOCP write interface if missing. If, however, Profit Center and Functional Area are mapped (and thus transferred from SAC), the correct profit center and functional area assignment is checked in SAP S/4HANA before writing plan data into table ACDOCP.  If this consistency check fails because, for example, the derived account assignment type returns a different profit center, an error message appears and the data transfer is aborted. Therefore, when mapping the functional area and/or profit center, ensure that the master data in SAP Analytics Cloud is up to date.
  • When using the SAP-delivered planning categories BUDGET01, BUDGET02 and BUDGET03 when writing into table ACDOCP,  the following default value for Budget Consistency Check (screenshot taken from SSCUI ID 102822) requires that additional (plan data scope) requirements be taken into account:For example, for project budget (planning category BUDGET01), plan data scope must NOT be active for WBSElement, FiscalPeriod, FiscalYearPeriod and CompanyCode. For the cost center budget (planning category BUDGET02), plan data scope must NOT be active for FiscalPeriod and FiscalYearPeriod.
  • Balance sheet data as part of financial statement planning requires a balance carry-forward logic to ensure that opening balance and balance sheet movements within a fiscal year are correctly replicated from SAC into table ACDOCP. Like in the SAC Export API, this requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA global field BalanceFlowType (see in below file configuration ID 30001).
  • Costs split into fixed and variable costs in SAC can also be replicated and stored in table ACDOCP, which requires mapping of the SAP S/4HANA field FixedVariableType. In this case, the data records split into fixed and variable are merged into one data record on the SAP S/4HANA side, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective ‚Äútotal‚Äù measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written into the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).

Example Configurations

Finally, the file in the following URL shows predefined configuration settings to give an idea of how to configure specific content in the mapping and filter section: https://d.dam.sap.com/a/MVuKTRq?rc=10&doi=SAP1225684

The first example (configuration ID 10001) from the file for OPEX-related plan data on cost centers and projects, including value-based allocations, is explained based on screenshots from the manage app:

Mapping of Financial Plan Data

  • For the SAC measure AMOUNT on the SAP S/4HANA side, the measure AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency is used (and the currency derived from a property of the company code), assuming the company code currency in SAC plan data.
  • The displayed plan data scope contains the mandatory plan data scope fields PlanningCategory, CompanyCode and FiscalYearPeriod (or LedgerFiscalYear) and is sufficient if there is no other overlapping configuration ID writing into the same planning category.
  • As described, ProfitCenter and FunctionalArea are not included, as this proposal relies on the derivation rules in SAP S/4HANA to derive the two fields in the background when writing plan data into table ACDOCP.
  • Including the source field FixedVariableType ensures that when writing into table ACDOCP the plan data is reformatted accordingly, i.e. the total value (sum of fixed and variable) is written to the respective ‚Äútotal‚Äù measures (e.g. AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency) and the fixed value is written to the respective fixed measure (e.g. FixedAmountInCoCodeCrcy).
  • In the example, the SAP Planning category PLN is used. Likewise, another category can be selected, which is maintained in SAP S/4HANA with Application Type ‚ÄúPeriodic Planning & Consolidation‚Äù and Category Usage ‚ÄúNO specific usage‚Äù (in SSCUI 101970, Maintain Category for Planning).

Filter Settings for Financial Plan Data

  • The mandatory single value filter for the source field Version is maintained here. In the IFP content, the version Plan is used by default and may need to be adjusted if it differs in the custom data model.
  • It should also be filtered by planning period to select the plan data to the respective planning year.
  • In this example, further filter settings are not necessary because, on the one hand, this configuration is for OPEX-related plan data including cost centers and projects and only the AMOUNT measure is mapped. Other measures are excluded (like measures related to allocation weights ).

entry.title: Developing a Customized AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Part 2
entry.content:
In this Part - 2, we'll dive into using the Custom Analytical Queries APP with our newly created Custom CDS View to build an AR Aging Analysis Report.

 

Please refer Part - 1 to Understand the Custom CDS View created for the AR Aging Analysis Report:

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/developing-a-customized-ar-aging-analysis-report-in-sap-s-4hana-public/qaq-p/14163727

 

Custom Analytical Queries APP:

The Custom Analytical Queries APP is like a smart tool that helps you create your own reports and analyze your business data, even if you're not a tech expert.

Imagine you're trying to build your Customer Aging Analysis Report. Instead of writing complex computer code, this app takes all the raw numbers and information (like invoices, payments, and dates) and turns them into an easy-to-understand table or grid. It hides all the difficult technical stuff, so you just focus on what you want to see.

Here's how it helps you design your report:

Pick and choose your data: The app provides all the available fields from the business transactions. For your aging report, you'd select fields like Customer Name, Invoice Number, Posting Date, Due Date, Amount Due, and Clearing Date.

Filter what you see: You can set filters to narrow down your report. For example, you might filter to see only particular customers, or invoices past their due date by more than 365 days.

Create custom calculations: You can add restricted measures (like "Total Overdue Amount for 30-60 Days").

See results instantly: You can preview your report as you build it, so you know exactly what the final output will look like.

 

Step ‚Äì 1: Open the APP ‚Äì Custom Analytical Queries

Click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button.

 

Enter the ‚ÄúQuery Name‚Äù, Choose the ‚ÄúData Source‚Äù ‚Äì which we have created as a CDS View.

Click on ‚ÄúOK‚Äù.

 

Step ‚Äì 2: Name the Analytical Query

In the General Tab,

Enter the ‚ÄúLabel‚Äù for the AR Aging Analysis Analytical Query and Click on Next Tab ‚ÄúField Selection‚Äù.

 

Step ‚Äì 3: Field Selection for the Analytical Query

In the Field Selection Tab,

Choose the required fields from the Available Fields by selecting the ‚ÄúCheck box‚Äù to display in the AR Aging Report.

 

Step ‚Äì 4: Arrange the Selected Fields in the Analytical Query

In the Display Tab,

Select relevant Field and Choose the ‚ÄúAxis‚Äù - Row / Column. Once selected the Axis, the field will be automatically moved to Row / Column Tab same as Company Code, Customer etc.

Note: Arrange the fields according to the business format and also Amounts / Numerical / Calculation related fields are arranged under the Measure Structure of Column Axis.

 

Step ‚Äì 5: Choose the Input Parameter Fields for the Report

For the AR Aging Analysis Report, users need to provide input parameters such as Open Items at Key Date, Customer, Company Code, GL Account, and Posting Date to generate the report based on their selections.

In the Filter Tab,

Choose the respective Field and then Select the radio button ‚ÄúUset Input Values‚Äù.

Select the ‚ÄúDefault Value‚Äù if required.

Note: Our AR Aging Analysis report runs based on the Open Items at Key Date, showing all items not cleared by that date. If you need to pre-fill any input fields, you can use the Default Value functionality in the filter section.

For Example: Below are the selected Input Parameters for our report and the ‚ÄúOpen Items at Key Date‚Äù and ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù will be defaulted at the time of report execution based on the settings in Analytical Queries.

Step ‚Äì 6: Create Calculated Measure Fields (Aging Buckets) for the Report

Creating Aging Buckets is the most challenging aspect of developing the AR Aging Analysis Report. This is primarily due to the complexity of applying the necessary formulas. To build custom aging buckets, you'll need a foundational understanding of IF & Else conditions, similar to those used in Excel, to grasp the CASE WHEN Expression formulas utilized in SAP Analytical Queries.

 

  1. Not Yet Due (Aging Bucket - 1)

In the Display Tab,

Click on ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button and Choose ‚ÄúAdd Calculated Measure‚Äù to create the Aging Bucket.

Then Enter the ‚ÄúLabel‚Äù and Click on ‚ÄúOK‚Äù.

We've now added a "Not Yet Due" field to the query. This field displays the Amount in Company Code Currency for any customer open items with Overdue Days less than or equal to zero.

The above logic has been applied in the analytical query using the CASE WHEN formula.

In the Expression Section,

Choose the ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù button to apply the formula.

Select the ‚ÄúFunction‚Äù button then Choose the ‚ÄúCase Expression‚Äù and Click on ‚ÄúOK‚Äù button.

The formula applied in this ‚ÄúNot Yet Due‚Äù field is, if the Overdue days field is less than or equal to ‚Äú0‚Äù then ‚ÄúAmount in Company Code Currency‚Äù should be displayed in the report or Else the value should be displayed as ‚Äú0‚Äù. You can Choose the Measure fields by click on measures button or else you can type relevant measure field in the Expression editor. Once formula applied the Click on ‚ÄúOK‚Äù.

 

  1. 1 to 30 Days (Aging Bucket ‚Äì 2)

Apply the same steps involved in Not Yet Due field, only the formula will be changed for this 1 to 30 Days Aging Bucket.

For the "1 to 30 Days" field, we've applied a specific formula:

If a Customer Open item's Overdue Days are greater than or equal to "1" AND less than or equal to "30," the Amount in Company Code Currency will be displayed. Otherwise, the value will show as "0." This formula uses an AND condition to accurately identify customer open items that are between 1 and 30 days overdue.

After applying the formula, simply click "OK."

 You can apply this formula and change the conditions according to the Aging Buckets (31 to 60 Days, 61 to 90 Days‚Ä¶etc).

The Sum of all the Aging Buckets from ‚Äú1 to 30 Days till Above 365 Days‚Äù will be the ‚ÄúTotal Overdue Amount‚Äù.

Once the respective fields created in the Custom Analytical Queries APP.

Click on ‚ÄúSave Draft‚Äù the changes will be saved. Then click on ‚ÄúPreview‚Äù option to validate the report values.

 

Step ‚Äì 7: Preview and Validate the Created Custom Analytical Query

In the Input Parameters, The Open Items at Key Date and Company Code will automatically default the value according to the settings in Custom Analytical Queries APP and also it can be changeable at the time of report executing.

Once maintained the Input Parameters, Click on ‚ÄúGO‚Äù.

You can validate the output of the report in the Preview. So, the issues will be identified and resolved before publishing the Custom Analytical Query for the APP creation.

 

Step ‚Äì 8: Publish the Created Custom Analytical Query for AR Aging Analysis Report

Click on ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù to publish the created Custom Analytical Query for the AR Aging Analysis Report APP creation.

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition key users, the View Browser app is essential for finding CDS views. This includes both SAP-released and custom CDS views.

The app provides a comprehensive list of available CDS views. You can see details like Category, View Types, Dimensions and Measures, Annotations, supported capabilities, and modelling patterns. Beyond searching, you can use the View Browser to analyze a CDS view's data fields. The application displays all CDS views and their underlying artifacts in tables. By default, views are organized by name, but you can also filter column values using a dropdown.

While you can't change SAP-created CDS views in the View Browser, the Custom Analytical Query app allows you to create, save, modify, and publish your own CDS views to catalogs.

entry.title: Workarounds for Planning inconsistancies occuring due to MRP live
entry.content:
Planning Inconsistency during MRP run using MRP live

Introduction

             Material Requirements Planning (MRP) is one of the core components within the Production Planning module of SAP ERP. Its primary function is to ensure material availability by systematically evaluating demand (PIR, CIR, S/O), existing inventory and procurement proposals (PRs/POs), and generating new proposals to bridge any identified shortages. This is essential for smooth production operations and timely delivery schedules

             As the 21st century unfolded, it ushered into a new age ‚Äì The digital age, the Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR), our period is marked by rapid digital transformation across industries. Every facet of the supply chain is being shifted toward digitization as much as possible, driven by the need for increased speed, transparency, efficiency, connectivity and scalability. At the same time, the volume and complexity of global business transactions surged, placing unprecedented pressure on legacy systems.

            In response to these evolving market needs, enterprise resource planning systems required a significant upgrade. The modern market needs 4IR compliant features such as such as high-capacity data storage and data retrieval, cloud computing, integration with IoT networks, intelligent automation through AI-ML and system scalability.

            Recognizing this shift, SAP launched its next-generation business suite‚ÄîSAP S/4HANA‚Äîin February 2015. One of its most transformative innovations (P.P. POV) was the introduction of MRP Live, a high-performance planning engine designed to meet the demands of real-time, data-driven operations, built to leverage the power of the HANA database, executes complex planning scenarios at unprecedented speed, with scalability and transparency tailored to the digital enterprise.

            However, as with any emerging technology during it‚Äôs infancy, MRP live also has it‚Äôs own constraints. More details of its restrictions are available on S/Note: 1914010. This article describes a scenario of planning inconsistency of MRP live and a work around to fix it.

Disclaimer

This observation is shared purely for educational purposes only and pertains to a specific scenario. MRP Live is a powerful and innovative tool, with high flexibility and possess robust cross-plant planning capabilities. The behavior noted here is an outlier case within a highly complex program. While a temporary workaround is suggested, it‚Äôs important to emphasize that, the final solution must come from SAP, as part of their continuous product improvement and support lifecycle."

Business Scenario

The material is maintained as a project stock. We maintain a planned independent requirement and procure the components, at the same time, we also receive sales orders. Sales order consumes PIR. Basically, it follows Planning with Final assembly, but with two changes:

  1. Since it‚Äôs under project stock, therefore for CIR, we assign assignment category ‚ÄúQ‚Äù
  2. The business scenario is such that, when S/O is created, Production order also need to be created automatically.

Configurations 

Practice scenario:

PIR:

Sales Order:

Stock Requirements screen:

We can observe two things

  1. Sales Order has consumed PIR.
  2. Production orders are created without MRP run as soon as Sales orders are saved.

Now Planning run using MRP live

 

Stock Requirements screen:

Pic: A

Creating a second sales order and executing MRP live:

Pic B

Observations

  1. Sales order consuming PIR properly ‚Äì Working as per standard.
  2. Compare Pic A & B, for Planned orders created from PIR, the latest sales order details are populated, to its account assignment category ‚Äì Planning inconsistency

Workarounds

Option 1: T-code: MD_MRP_FORCE_CLASSIC

To correct this planning inconsistency, we must force this material to plan in classic MRP, no matter if planning run is done via classic MRP or MRP live. Refer to S/Note: 2883907 for further information. Although we get the correct planning results, we lose the advantages of MRP live.

Planning run with MRP live.

Result

Observation:

  1. Now the S/O order details are not being populated to Planned orders created from PIRs, therefore no planning inconsistancies.

Option 2: Activate ‚ÄúAssign effectivity parameter values/ override change numbers‚Äù

Turn off the Classic MRP check box

Now when planned using MRP live, material will be again planned under MRP live program, leading to planning inconsistancies.

Now activate Assign effect. vals

Although the purpose of Assign effect. Vals is different, but according to S/Note: 1914010, MRP Live on HANA does not support parameter effectivity. Therefore, by default, the materials will be planned by Classic MRP.

These are the two workarounds to force materials to be planned using Classic MRP.

Summary

1. Although, MRP live is a very powerful tool, it has it's own limitations (S/Note: 1914010), that can cause inconsistancies in planning. Therefore sometimes we need to force the material to plan in Classical MRP at the cost of MRP live advantages. 

2. To force material to plan in classic MRP, use T-code: MD_MRP_FORCE_CLASSIC, and check the classic MRP box.

3. If you consider, MD_MRP_FORCE_CLASSIC, as additional step, you can simply check the "Assign effect. Vals" in basic data 1 view of material master. Although it's puspose is different, it server the purpose in this case.
